Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Improving Energy Reliability by Co-Optimization Planning for Interdependent Electricity and Natural Gas Infrastructure Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The electricity grid and the natural gas network are two essential infrastructure systems in the U.S. energy industry. They are designed and managed independently. However, because of the planned retirement of many coal-fired generators, the deeper penetration of renewable energy sources, and the commercially sustainable gas price, their interactions have intensified over the last five years. Hence, in order to ensure environmentally friendly, reliable, and cost-effective electricity and gas production and delivery, it is important to jointly optimize these two systems. However, due to their scales, complexities, and requirements/regulations, such a co-optimization planning problem is very challenging in both modeling and computation aspects. To address this critical challenge, this project will build analytical decision support models and design efficient solution methods to aid the energy industry in formulating and computing practical-scale co-optimization problems. The effectiveness and benefit of co-optimization planning will be demonstrated and evaluated through an actual microgrid project and industrial collaborations. In addition to including doctoral students in research and creating educational materials for the next generation energy system planners and operations researchers, concrete projects will be designed to involve underrepresented students on utilizing analytical/computational tools to address real energy problems.

Previous research on co-optimization planning of electricity and gas systems is limited, while also often neglecting critical reliability considerations, key random/uncertain factors, or the long-term multi-stage nature of planning problems. This research project will address these shortcomings by (1) investigating key interactions between electricity and gas systems with different spatial-temporal granularities as well as multiple planning and operation levels; (2) building a set of co-optimization planning models that simultaneously consider the multi-stage planning horizon, the hourly chronological operation details with critical random/uncertain factors, and the requirements of long-term reliability and short-term flexibility; (3) designing and implementing high-performance computational methods and tools through advanced decomposition strategies, strong approximation approaches, and effective hybrid methods; and (4) validating, demonstrating, and promoting the developed models and computational tools through an on-going microgrid project and established industry connections.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electricity grid and natural gas network are two essential infrastructure systems in the U.S. energy sector. Traditionally, because coal has been the primary fuel to power plants with a long history, these two systems evolve rather independently. Nevertheless, with serious concerns over environmental sustainability and more stringent environmental regulations, many coal-fired generators (i.e., units) are being replaced by lower-emitting gas-fired units and renewable energy. Moreover, because of their fast ramping capabilities, gas-fired units are highly demanded to firm up renewable energy for a deeper penetration.

Given the critical role of gas-fired units, their dependence on gas network, and their low priority in gas supply, it is greatly desired by various stakeholders to jointly co-optimize electricity and natural gas systems. However, existing study on co-optimization planning of these two systems, which is very limited, neglects critical reliability considerations, key random factors, or the long-term multi-stage planning nature. In addition, no fast algorithms or tools are available to support practical-scale applications. As result, co-optimization planning remains as a new and challenging problem to the power industry.

To address such a crucial issue, this project has thoroughly investigated interactions between electricity and natural gas systems, developed analytical decision support models to fully consider reliability, key random factors, and important technological and operational characteristics, and design efficient computational methods and tools. Specifically the team has developed analytical models and computational methods to investigate several issues related to the electricity and natural gas systems interactions for enhancing operational security and economics of the integrated energy system, including: (i) the coordinated optimal energy flow (including both electric power flow and gas flow) by considering their physical interactions; (ii) the coordinated demand response of the energy system (both electricity demand and gas demand) while considering uncertainties; (iii) the simulation and evaluation of the bi-directional cascading failure propagation in an integrated electricity-natural gas system, while considering the distinct time response behaviors of the two systems as well as the energy coupling components such as gas-fired generators and electricity-driven gas compressors; (iv) the identification and ranking of vulnerable components of interdependent natural gas-electricity systems by combining a topological model and the vulnerability index for the interdependent system; and (v) the coordinated short-term schedule and real-time dispatch of an integrated electricity-natural gas system with energy coupling components (i.e., power to gas assets and gas-fired generators), in order to mitigate potential gas pressure violations induced by wind power uncertainties in real time. Research results have been validated, demonstrated, and promoted via the established industry connections, and ultimately support co-optimization planning of these two systems to ensure environmentally friendly, reliable, and cost-effective electricity and gas production and delivery.

In this project, 3 graduate students have been involved in various research and education activities. The team published 8 journal papers to disseminate research results supported by this project. Some research findings have been included in a graduate level course on ?Smart Grid? at Stevens Institute of Technology. The PI has also delivered several invited talks to disseminate research results supported by this project.
